visuals.title: Common-Emitter Amplifier Circuit
visuals.description: The CE amplifier: input at base via C_in, output at collector. R_C sets the load, R_E provides DC stability, C_E bypasses R_E for AC.

visuals.title: CE DC Load Line and Q-Point
visuals.description: The load line V_CE = V_CC - I_C(R_C + R_E) intersects the BJT curves at the Q-point.

visuals.title: CE Voltage Gain: A_V = -g_m × R_C
visuals.description: The CE amplifier inverts the signal. Gain magnitude depends on g_m (set by Q-point) and R_C.

visuals.title: CE Input Impedance: R_in = r_π || R₁ || R₂
visuals.description: Input impedance is dominated by r_π = β/g_m. For β=100, g_m=40mS: r_π = 2.5kΩ.

visuals.title: CE Output: Phase Inversion
visuals.description: The CE amplifier inverts the signal: positive input → negative output swing. This 180° phase shift is characteristic of CE.

visuals.title: CE Frequency Response (Bode Plot)
visuals.description: Low-frequency cutoff due to coupling/bypass capacitors. High-frequency rolloff due to device capacitances and Miller effect.

visuals.title: CE Power Gain — Highest Among BJT Configs
visuals.description: CE provides high voltage gain AND current gain (β), giving the highest power gain A_P = A_V × A_I.

visuals.title: CE Small-Signal Parameters Summary
visuals.description: Key parameters: A_V = -g_m·R_C, R_in ≈ r_π, R_out ≈ R_C, A_I ≈ β.

visuals.title: Effect of Emitter Degeneration (Unbypassed R_E)
visuals.description: Adding R_E in the AC path reduces gain but improves linearity and stability. A_V = -R_C/(r_e + R_E).

visuals.title: Thermal Stability: I_C vs Temperature
visuals.description: Without R_E, I_C increases with temperature (thermal runaway). R_E provides negative feedback for thermal stability.
